description: Deep analysis of counterfactual reasoning using Lewis-Stalnaker possible worlds semantics and historical counterfactual methodology. Reveals whether 'what if' claims follow the minimal rewrite principle, identifies closest possible worlds, traces causal chains through counterfactual scenarios, and evaluates historical plausibility using Lebow/Tetlock criteria. Exposes butterfly effects, cotenability violations, and counterfactual abuse where authors slide between backtracking and non-backtracking readings to suit their arguments.
researcher_question: What counterfactual claims are being made, do they follow sound methodology, and what do they actually establish about causation?

counterfactual_claims.name: string (evocative name like 'The No-Hitler Scenario' or 'The Brexit Reversal')
counterfactual_claims.full_statement: string (the complete counterfactual as stated or reconstructed)
counterfactual_claims.domain: string (politics, economics, technology, social, military, etc.)

antecedent_conditions.antecedent_type: event_deletion | event_insertion | property_change | timing_change | actor_substitution | decision_reversal

possible_worlds.name: string (evocative name like 'World Without WWI' or 'The Gore Presidency')
possible_worlds.description: string (key features of this possible world)
possible_worlds.relationship_to_actual: string (how it differs from actual history)
possible_worlds.similarity_score: number (0-1, closeness to actual world) | null
closer_than: world_id (PW{N}) - worlds this is closer than
farther_than: world_id (PW{N}) - worlds this is farther than

similarity_orderings.name: string (name of the similarity metric used)

minimal_rewrite_assessments.violation_type: none | excess_changes | butterfly_proliferation | gratuitous_differences | scope_creep | null
minimal_rewrite_assessments.violation_description: string (how minimal rewrite is violated) | null

miracle_assessments.avoidance_strategy: string (how to get same antecedent without miracle) | null
miracle_assessments.lewisian_severity: string (how Lewis would rank this miracle)

causal_chains.name: string (evocative name for the causal pathway)

links.is_backtracking: boolean (does this run backward in time)

cotenability_constraints.name: string (what must be held fixed)
cotenability_constraints.constraint_type: laws_of_nature | historical_facts | institutional_structures | psychological_dispositions | technological_capabilities | social_conditions
cotenability_constraints.justification: string (why this should be held fixed)
cotenability_constraints.violation_consequence: string (what happens if this isn't held fixed)

backtracking_analyses.backtracking_description: string (if backtracking: what past changes are implied) | null
backtracking_analyses.non_backtracking_description: string (if non-backtracking: what is held fixed) | null
backtracking_analyses.alternative_reading_yields: string (what the other reading would give)

lebow_criteria.clarity: high | medium | low (is antecedent precisely specified)
lebow_criteria.projectability: high | medium | low (can we trace consequences)

decision_points.description: string (moment where things could have gone differently)

overdetermination_cases.name: string (name for this overdetermination case)
overdetermination_cases.counterfactual_implications: string (what this means for counterfactual reasoning)

preemption_cases.name: string (name for this preemption case)
preemption_cases.counterfactual_problem: string (why this is tricky for counterfactuals)

second_order_counterfactuals.name: string (name for this nested counterfactual)
second_order_counterfactuals.structure: string (if it were the case that [if P then Q], then R)
second_order_counterfactuals.second_order_consequent: string (what follows from the first-order being true)

objective_possibility_assessments.thought_experiment_validity: string (does this work as a thought experiment)

counterfactual_abuses.name: string (evocative name for the abuse pattern)
counterfactual_abuses.abuse_type: cherry_picking_worlds | backtracking_slide | butterfly_exploitation | miracle_hiding | cotenability_manipulation | false_precision | scope_creep | counterfactual_stacking
counterfactual_abuses.rhetorical_purpose: string (what it accomplishes for the author)

nodes.type: string (counterfactual_claim | antecedent | consequent | possible_world | similarity_ordering | minimal_rewrite | miracle | causal_chain | cotenability | backtracking | plausibility | contingency | overdetermination | preemption | second_order | objective_possibility | quality | abuse)
nodes.label: string (short display name, 2-5 words)

clusters.name: string (evocative cluster name like 'The WWII Counterfactual Complex')

key_insights: string (major findings about counterfactual reasoning in corpus)

extraction.core_question: What counterfactual claims are being made, do they follow sound possible-worlds methodology, and what do they actually establish?
extraction_steps: STEP 1: IDENTIFY ALL COUNTERFACTUAL CLAIMS - Scan for explicit counterfactuals ('if X had happened, then Y') and implicit ones (causal claims that entail counterfactual commitments). Mark each with CF{N}. Note: Every causal claim 'X caused Y' implicitly commits to the counterfactual 'if not-X, then not-Y'.

STEP 2: DECOMPOSE INTO ANTECEDENT AND CONSEQUENT - For each counterfactual, isolate the antecedent (what is supposed contrary to fact) and consequent (what is claimed to follow). Classify antecedent type: event_deletion, event_insertion, property_change, timing_change, actor_substitution, or decision_reversal.

STEP 3: APPLY THE MINIMAL REWRITE PRINCIPLE - Per Lewis, the closest possible world where the antecedent is true should differ from the actual world only in what is required to make the antecedent true plus its lawful consequences. Ask: Does this counterfactual change MORE than necessary? Does it smuggle in additional changes beyond the minimal requirements? Flag all butterfly effect chains that spiral beyond control.

STEP 4: ASSESS MIRACLE REQUIREMENTS - What kind of 'miracle' (Lewis's term for law violation) is needed to get the antecedent? Lewis ranks worlds: avoid big miracles first, then maximize region of perfect match, then avoid small miracles. A counterfactual requiring radical violations of physical or psychological laws invokes a very distant world.

STEP 5: IDENTIFY THE POSSIBLE WORLD BEING INVOKED - What is the closest possible world where the antecedent holds? Map its key features. Is it genuinely the CLOSEST world, or has the author cherry-picked a convenient distant world?

STEP 6: CONSTRUCT THE SIMILARITY ORDERING - Using Lewis's criteria, evaluate: (1) absence of big miracles, (2) maximization of spatiotemporal region of perfect match, (3) absence of small miracles, (4) approximate similarity of particular facts. Is the author's implicit ordering defensible?

STEP 7: DETERMINE BACKTRACKING VS NON-BACKTRACKING READING - Is this a backtracking counterfactual (changing the past's past to get the antecedent) or non-backtracking (holding the past fixed up to a miracle at the antecedent time)? Lewis's standard semantics prefers non-backtracking, but some contexts require backtracking. CRITICAL: Watch for authors who slide between readings mid-argument.

STEP 8: TRACE THE CAUSAL CHAIN - Map each link from antecedent to consequent. For each link: What's the mechanism? What's the confidence? Is there counterfactual dependence? (Does the later event counterfactually depend on the earlier?) Flag any links that assume away obvious obstacles.

STEP 9: CHECK COTENABILITY CONSTRAINTS - What must be held fixed for the counterfactual to work? Are these constraints reasonable? Goodman's cotenability problem: you can't just hold EVERYTHING fixed except the antecedent. What's the justified scope of ceteris paribus?

STEP 10: APPLY LEBOW'S HISTORICAL PLAUSIBILITY CRITERIA - Is the antecedent clearly specified? Is it consistent with the historical context (actors' beliefs, available options)? Does it connect to a defensible causal theory? Can we plausibly project the consequences?

STEP 11: APPLY TETLOCK'S THOUGHT EXPERIMENT CRITERIA - Is this a well-specified antecedent that experts could evaluate? Does it avoid runaway butterfly effects? Could reasonable experts converge on likelihood judgments?

STEP 12: ASSESS WEBER'S OBJECTIVE POSSIBILITY - Is the antecedent nomologically possible (consistent with laws)? Is there adequate causation (would the antecedent, given what we know, have been likely to produce the consequent)?

STEP 13: CHECK FOR OVERDETERMINATION AND PREEMPTION - Was the actual outcome overdetermined (multiple sufficient causes)? Was there preemption (a backup cause would have produced the same effect)? These cases break simple counterfactual reasoning.

STEP 14: IDENTIFY SECOND-ORDER COUNTERFACTUALS - Does the argument involve counterfactuals about counterfactuals? ('If we had believed that intervention would fail, we wouldn't have intervened, and then X'). These compound the uncertainty.

STEP 15: CATALOG COUNTERFACTUAL ABUSES - Flag: cherry_picking_worlds (choosing convenient but distant worlds), backtracking_slide (switching readings mid-argument), butterfly_exploitation (tracing only favorable consequences), miracle_hiding (not acknowledging required violations), false_precision (claiming certainty about distant counterfactual outcomes).
STEP 16: SYNTHESIZE QUALITY ASSESSMENT - Using all previous analyses, rate the counterfactual's overall quality and provide specific improvement recommendations.
extraction.special_instructions: CRITICAL: For every counterfactual, you MUST determine whether it follows the minimal rewrite principle. This is the single most common failure in counterfactual reasoning. Ask: 'Is this the smallest change needed?' Also mandatory: identify whether the reading is backtracking or non-backtracking, and flag any mid-argument shifts between readings - this is a major source of counterfactual abuse.

consolidation_rules: RULE 1: MERGE EQUIVALENT COUNTERFACTUALS - Combine counterfactuals with the same antecedent-consequent structure even if worded differently. Preserve all sources.
RULE 2: CHAIN PRESUPPOSITIONAL COUNTERFACTUALS - If CF1 presupposes CF2, represent this dependency explicitly. Create ordered chains.
RULE 3: UNIFY POSSIBLE WORLDS - When multiple counterfactuals invoke the same or highly similar possible worlds, consolidate into single world representation.
RULE 4: AGGREGATE QUALITY ASSESSMENTS - When same counterfactual assessed multiple times, synthesize into single assessment noting any disagreements.
RULE 5: FLAG CONTRADICTORY COUNTERFACTUALS - When documents make incompatible counterfactual claims, preserve both and mark the contradiction.
RULE 6: PRESERVE STRONGEST OBJECTIONS - When a counterfactual's quality is challenged, preserve the strongest version of the challenge.
curation.special_instructions: Pay special attention to cases where different documents use THE SAME counterfactual (e.g., 'what if Hitler had died in 1938') but reach different conclusions - this reveals differences in implicit similarity orderings or causal assumptions.

id_examples.to: World Without the Assassination of Franz Ferdinand
The Butterfly Exploitation in Vietnam Arguments

concretization.naming_guidance: Names should capture the historical/concrete content of the counterfactual. Prefer specific: 'The No-D-Day Scenario' over 'Military Counterfactual 3'. Include key actors, dates, or events in names. Quality assessments should indicate the verdict in the name.
recommended_table_types: quality_matrix (cf_id, minimal_rewrite, cotenability, plausibility, backtracking, overall)
recommended_visual_patterns: possible_worlds_proximity_map (worlds as nodes, edges weighted by similarity)
backtracking_timeline (showing what gets held fixed vs what changes)
